overview_of_class: This course concerns the scientific study of human memory. In a discussion format, students will learn about the experimental methods as well as the principles of human memory that are revealed with these methods. Each week students will analyze research results in detail to determine whether scientists' conclusions are convincing. Students will learn to think carefully about how scientists gain knowledge about various aspects of human memory, including encoding, retrieval, consolidation, false remembering, and forgetting. A cognitive neuroscience perspective will be emphasized.
name: Human Memory
title: WCAS PSYCH 368-0-20 Human Memory

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisites: Psych 361 or 363. Students must also complete Psych 205 before taking this course.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Student-led presentations and class discussion guided by the instructor.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on participation in class discussion, short papers due before every class, presentations, an initial version of the final paper, and the final paper.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Readings gathered from the contemporary literature on human memory (available online), along with an optional textbook, Memory (First or Second Edition), by Alan Baddeley, Michael W. Eysench, and Michael C. Anderson, Psychology Press, 2015. Paperback - ISBN: 978-1-84872-184-5
